''LIGHTING a historic building poses a multitude of historic problems,'' writes Dr. Roger W. Moss in ''Lighting For Historic Buildings,'' the last volume in the Historic Interiors Series published by the Preservation Press in Washington. Among the challenges are selecting appropriate light fixtures and duplicating historic light levels.

As Dr. Moss, executive director of the Athenaeum of Philadelphia, said, ''Even if the homeowner or curator wanted to cope with rooms illuminated by candles, oil, burning fluid, gas or kerosene, a host of necessary regulations designed to protect building occupants stands in the way.''

The book is a knowledgeable guide to reproduction lighting, including electric hall lights, pendants and lanterns, crystal prisms and fabric lamp shades. Other volumes in the series cover floor and wall coverings.
The books cost $12.95 each, plus $3 for shipping, from Mail Order, National Trust for Historic Preservation, 1600 H Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20006.
